channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rishi Sunak Wins Contest to be UK’s Next PM and Confront Economic Storm
item.description: After a period of chaos, Mr. Sunak, a Conservative, faces serious political and economic headwinds. He will be the first person of color and first Hindu to be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, center, outside Conservative Party headquarters in London on Monday.

item.title: Russian Officials Flee Kherson as Russian Troops Dig In for a Battle
item.description: In Kherson, the first Ukrainian city to fall after the Russian invasion, occupation forces appear to be preparing to fight advancing Ukrainian troops.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a heavily shelled schoolyard in the Kherson region, Ukrainian troops searched for explosives and booby traps on Monday.

item.title: Where Russians Retreated, Ukrainians Find Devastation
item.description: Returning to liberated towns, Ukrainians find destruction on a staggering scale, vital services cut, and the prospect of a lethal winter ahead.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: Sunak’s Ascent Is a Breakthrough for Diversity, With Privilege
item.description: Rishi Sunak’s ascent to the prime minister’s office is a significant milestone for Britain’s Indian diaspora. But for many, his immense personal wealth has made him less relatable.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating Diwali in northwest London on Monday. As many as 1.5 million people of Indian descent live in England and Wales, making them the largest ethnic group after white Britons.

item.title: How Rich Is Rishi Sunak, Britain’s Incoming Prime Minister?
item.description: Just how rich is the soon-to-be prime minister of Britain?
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, at a reception in February for the British Asian Trust in London.

item.title: Venezuelan Migrants Stranded After US Border Policy Change
item.description: They have sold their belongings and trekked across a deadly jungle. Now, tens of thousands Venezuelan migrants are stranded south of the United States, with nowhere to go.
item.dc:creator: David Shortell and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelan migrants on a hill near the border with United States in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. The United States has started turning back many Venezuelans reaching the border.

item.title: Brazil’s Polls Were Wrong. Now the Right Wants to Criminalize Them.
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro and conservative lawmakers in Brazil are trying to make it illegal to publish polls that later do not match the election results.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in the first round of elections in Sao Paulo earlier this month.

item.title: Ethiopian Government and Tigray Rebels Are Set to Begin Peace Talks
item.description: Delegations from both sides have traveled to South Africa for the first formal negotiations since the civil war erupted nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A demonstration in Addis Ababa in support of the Ethiopia armed forces this past weekend.

item.title: South African Leader Unveils Anticorruption Plans, but Doubts Follow
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa presented measures that would place even himself and his cabinet under scrutiny. But some analysts question whether the plan will be carried out.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa came to power after the scandal-plagued Zuma years and was seen as someone who could right the ship, an analyst said.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Troops Will Fight for Key City as Proxy Government Flees
item.description: There were growing signs that the occupation government in the southern city of Kherson was preparing the city for fighting ahead of a possible Ukrainian counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Rishi Sunak Will Become the U.K.’s Next Prime Minister on Tuesday
item.description: The former chancellor of the Exchequer is set to become the first person of color to lead Britain. He will face a range of dire economic challenges and promised to bring his “party and country together.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, center, with members of the 1922 committee in Parliament on Monday after he was announced as the Conservative Party’s new leader.

item.title: For Ukrainian Runners, a Brutal Race Made Sense When Little Else Did
item.description: Backyard ultramarathons are grueling, hourslong races. The international team competition, held on Oct. 15, included runners from dozens of nations racing on their home turf, including Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jared Beasley
item.media:credit: Alexey Furman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Runners on the Ukrainian team competing in the Backyard Ultra Satellite Team Championships.

item.title: US Executives Are Flocking to Saudi Davos in the Desert
item.description: Some top American business leaders are headed to the Saudi business conference. But Biden administration officials, angry over the kingdom’s stance on oil production and ties with Russia, are staying away.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guests arriving in 2019 for the Future Investment Initiative conference, nicknamed “Davos in the Desert,” in the Saudi capital, Riyadh.

item.title: Xi Jinping Now Holds Near-Absolute Power in China, Creating Risks
item.description: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Chang Che
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, left, with new members of the Politburo Standing Committee at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Why People Are Flocking to a Symbol of Taiwan’s Authoritarian Past
item.description: At a museum dedicated to Taiwan’s not-so-distant authoritarian past, Taiwanese see China’s present, and a dark vision of one possible future under autocratic rule.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Chris Horton
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jing-Mei White Terror Memorial Park in Taiwan has seen a surge of visitors since Speaker Nancy Pelosi toured the site in August.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Britain’s next leader.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: 3 Palestinians Killed in Shootout With Israeli Forces, Palestinians Say
item.description: Three Palestinians were killed during a firefight with Israeli security forces who had entered Nablus, a flash point city in the occupied West Bank, Palestinian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Men carrying the body of Hamdi Sharaf in Nablus, in the occupied West Bank early on Tuesday. Palestinian officials said he was one of three people killed in a clash with Israeli security forces.

item.title: Dietrich Mateschitz, Creator of the Red Bull Empire, Dies at 78
item.description: The Austrian salesman turned a Thai energy drink into a marketing juggernaut that owned sports teams, media outlets and a winning Formula 1 crew.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Dietrich Mateschitz was a salesman for a company that made personal hygiene products when he discovered the elixirs sold in Asian pharmacies as pick-me-ups for workers and truckers.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Rishi Sunak to Lead Britain
item.description: Plus Chinese markets react to a stronger Xi Jinping and young Chinese pursue quiet dissent.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: What Will Rishi Sunak Do as UK’s Prime Minister?
item.description: He has said very little about how he will turn around Britain’s economy or deal with any of the other issues facing the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak in Cardiff, Wales, in August. Mr. Sunak has said very little in the last week about how he will lead Britain.

item.title: Brittney Griner Doesn’t Expect ‘Miracles to Happen’ With Her Appeal
item.description: If the appeals court won’t overrule Ms. Griner’s verdict, it will come into force and she will be sent to a penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Rishi Sunak Will Face Difficult Economic Tests Immediately
item.description: As prime minister, Mr. Sunak will face a vastly different economic backdrop to the one he experienced as finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canary Wharf, a finaincial center in London. The government is under pressure to show how it will keep borrowing in check, in an effort to restore Britain’s fiscal credibility in markets.

item.title: What Will Happen Next to Become UK Prime Minister?
item.description: Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak must now visit Buckingham Palace to meet with King Charles III, who will invite Mr. Sunak to form the next government.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, in one of her last official duties, met with Liz Truss last month after the lawmaker was named the Tories’ leader.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Makes History as UK’s First Prime Minister of Color
item.description: Born in southern England to parents of Indian heritage, he has spoken of a childhood split between the Hindu temple and cheering on the local soccer team.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Shashank Bengali and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer, in August.

item.title: Italy’s New Right-Wing Government Promises to Keep Backing Ukraine
item.description: Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani expressed support for Ukraine, trying to dispel concerns that Italy could undercut Europe’s opposition to the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Italy’s new prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, center, with her coalition partners Silvio Berlusconi, left, and Matteo Salvini, right.

item.title: A Republican Advantage
item.description: As headlines shift in the weeks before the midterms, so do voters’ top concerns.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: How to Watch the Partial Solar Eclipse This Week
item.description: The event will be visible from Europe, northern Africa, the Middle East and Asia on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: A partial solar eclipse over the Houses of Parliament in London in June 2021.

item.title: Sunak was the clear front-runner.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: As Israel Votes, Again, Netanyahu Pins Hopes on the Far Right
item.description: To regain power, Benjamin Netanyahu, the longest-serving Israeli prime minister, will most likely need the support of Itamar Ben-Gvir, a far-right leader with a history of extreme views.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Ben-Gvir during a night walk with supporters on Thursday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Western Allies Reject Russia’s ‘Dirty Bomb’ Claims
item.description: Diplomats from France, Britain and the United States called Russia’s allegation a pretext that Moscow has concocted for escalating the war.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin and Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu in August. Mr. Shoigu held calls with his counterparts from France, the U.S. and Britain over the weekend.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Britain’s leadership race.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Boris Johnson outside Downing Street, in London, last month.

item.title: Climate Activists Throw Mashed Potatoes on Monet Painting
item.description: The stunt in a German museum was the latest attack on widely admired art, carried out by protesters demanding action on climate change.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: After throwing mashed potatoes at a painting by Claude Monet, on exhibit in Potsdam, Germany, the climate protesters each glued a hand to the wall on Sunday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Becomes the Front Runner for U.K. Prime Minister
item.description: Mr. Sunak’s warnings about inflation and his fiscal conservatism may have cost him the post in September. But now his accurate assessments are easing his path to Britain’s top job.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak at a Conservative Party event in London in August.

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Statement on Withdrawing From Race
item.description: The former prime minister cited concerns about a divided party.
item.media:description: Boris Johnson last month on his last day as prime minister, outside Downing Street in London. He was followed in office by Liz Truss, who resigned last week.

item.title: As Russia and Ukraine Seek Gains on Front Line, U.S. and Allies Warn Moscow
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III held a call with Russia’s defense chief to discuss President Vladimir Putin’s nuclear threats.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Helene Cooper and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gravedigger at work Sunday in a cemetery in the Dnipro region for members of the Ukrainian armed forces killed since Russia invaded on Feb. 24.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Xi Jinping Consolidates Power
item.description: Plus Britain prepares for a new leader and Russia forcibly resettles Ukraine’s children.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: A display featuring Chinese President Xi Jinping at The Museum of the Communist Party in October.

item.title: More Ukrainian Officials Accuse Russia of Slowing Grain Shipments
item.description: A U.N.-brokered deal ended a five-month Russian blockade of Ukrainian ports and freed millions of tons of agricultural products for a 120-day period.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cargo vessel filled with grain at Port Pivdennyi, Ukraine, in August.

item.title: Ngo Vinh Long, Lightning Rod for Opposing the Vietnam War, Dies at 78
item.description: After escaping arrest in Vietnam for his antiwar views, he became the most prominent Vietnamese in the United States to campaign against the war.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans

item.title: Russian Fighter Jet Crashes Into a Home in Serbia, Killing Two Pilots
item.description: The crash in Irkutsk was the second of a Russian warplane in a residential area within a week.
item.dc:creator: Matt Surman
item.media:description: Irkutsk, Russia, after a fighter jet crashed into a residential area on Sunday.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Army is Pioneering Anti-Drone Warfare
item.description: With an intense, hastily assembled effort, the Ukrainian military is pioneering successful techniques in the difficult art of anti-drone warfare.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Police officers in Kyiv, Ukraine, trying to shoot down a drone during an attack on Oct. 17. The drone was believed to be an Iranian-made Shahed-136, purchased by Russia in August.

item.title: Boris Johnson Drops Out of UK Prime Minister Race
item.description: Pulling out of the race to succeed Liz Truss, the former prime minister eased a path for Rishi Sunak, his former chancellor of Britain’s treasury.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Boris Johnson outside Downing Street, in London, last month.

item.title: Republicans’ Persistent 2020 Election Doubts
item.description: Hundreds of Republicans running for offices this year have questioned the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu

item.title: Russian Superyachts in Turkey Raise Concerns in Washington
item.description: Turkey’s welcoming ports are symptoms of a much larger problem: evasion of U.S. sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Elif Ince, Michael Forsythe and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Elif Ince for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solaris, a superyacht linked to the Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, in the Yalıkavak Bay in Bodrum, Turkey, in August.

item.title: China’s Politburo Has No Women, a Break With Custom
item.description: For the first time in decades, the Politburo has no female members. And no woman has ever been included in the even more exclusive and powerful Standing Committee.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Shen Yiqin, the party secretary of Guizhou Province, at the party congress on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Authorities Tell Civilians to ‘Immediately’ Leave Kherson
item.description: Kherson, which was captured by Russia early in the war, is a major industrial port city and the capital of the one of the four regions Russia has illegally annexed.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Civilians relocated from the Russian-controlled city of Kherson arriving by ferry in Oleshky, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: A loyal aide in Shanghai takes a leading role in Beijing.
item.description: Li Qiang is now China’s second-highest official after Xi Jinping. Mr. Li’s time in Shanghai had raised questions about whether he would rise to the party’s highest levels.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Li Qiang, the Communist Party chief of Shanghai, at the opening of the party congress in Beijing.

item.title: How Political Primaries Drive Britain’s Dysfunction
item.description: In the United States, too, the rise of inside-party primaries has empowered candidates at the extremes, and the result is likely to be a greater disconnect with the public.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: 10 Downing Street in London, where Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned this week. Ms. Truss was only the fourth British leader to win the job through a party primary.

item.title: How China’s top leadership is selected.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A meeting of Communist Party leaders last week. The party’s most important decisions on top positions are often made through back-room dealings.

item.title: Xi is expected to unveil a new lineup of top officials.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: China’s President Xi Jinping and other senior members of the government raised their hands to vote during the closing session of the party congress in Beijing, on Saturday.

item.title: Hu Jintao Was Escorted Out of China’s Congress, Raising Questions
item.description: A health scare? A brazen political gesture? Whatever else it was, the episode was awkward.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:description: The unexpected departure of a former leader, Hu Jintao, standing, who apparently paused to speak to Mr. Xi before being escorted out, caused a brief stir during in proceedings that are usually tightly choreographed.

item.title: Roslyn Moves Inland and Breaks Up After Lashing Mexican Coast
item.description: The storm, which made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane, brought coastal flooding and dangerous winds to the country’s Pacific Coast, killing at least three people.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Hurricane Roslyn flooded streets in Puerto Vallarta, in Jalisco State in Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: Ian Hamilton, 97, Who Stole a Scottish Relic From Westminster Abbey, Dies
item.description: In an audacious caper, he and three other Scottish nationalists liberated the Stone of Destiny nearly 700 years after England had seized it from Scotland.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Ian Hamilton in 1951. To him, the theft was the rightful repatriation of a symbol of Scottish independence.

item.title: Boris Johnson Returns to Britain and Gains Support for Prime Minister Bid
item.description: The former Conservative leader, who was forced out of office after scandals this summer, hasn’t declared his candidacy, but dozens of party lawmakers already support him.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Boris Johnson on Saturday at Gatwick Airport near London after returning from a vacation. While he was away, Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned.

item.title: Some Palestinians Move Into Caves to Resist Israeli Expulsion
item.description: Israel’s Supreme Court has ordered the removal of about 1,200 Palestinians from their villages in the occupied West Bank. The United Nations says that could amount to a war crime.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Abu Sabha family in July in a cave in Khirbet al-Fakheit, a village in the West Bank. The family’s home was destroyed three times, so they turned to the cave.

item.title: Did the Pandemic Change Your Personality? Possibly.
item.description: For more than two years, Covid disrupted social rituals and rites of passage. Now a recent study suggests we have become less extroverted, creative, agreeable and conscientious. The declines in some traits were sharper among young people.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy Nguyen participates in a group scream at the Zionsville Youth Soccer Fields in Whitestown, Indiana.

item.title: How Tumultuous Forces of Brexit Divided U.K.’s Conservative Party
item.description: Some experts link Liz Truss’s downfall to the ripple effect of Britain’s departure from the European Union and the bitter, ideologically opposed factions it created in her party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brexit supporters gathering in front of a statue of Winston Churchill in London on Jan. 21, 2020, to celebrate Britain leaving the European Union.

item.title: Scare Tactics
item.description: It’s Halloween season, time for two-pound bags of fun-size candy and scary movies that haunt your dreams.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Getting People Back on Trains, After the Pandemic Turned Many to Cars
item.description: While the federal government is committed to a multibillion-dollar improvement to train service, an already long schedule may face delays.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The federal government has said it is committed to a new passenger rail line through Ontario and Quebec.
